## Executive Summary

This report analyzes Netflix's Top 10 global and country-specific viewing data to identify successful "gourmet cheeseburgers" - high-quality content that appeals to mass audiences worldwide. Our analysis reveals compelling insights about Netflix's global reach, content performance, and regional preferences that support strategic press releases highlighting the platform's continued success.

Key findings include Netflix's operation across **`r length(unique(COUNTRY_TOP_10$country_name))`** countries, with standout performers like *Squid Game* achieving unprecedented global viewership and *Stranger Things* maintaining consistent international appeal across multiple seasons.

## Introduction

As Netflix continues its mission to create compelling original content with global appeal, understanding viewing patterns across different markets becomes crucial for strategic communication. This analysis examines Netflix's public Top 10 data to quantify recent successes and identify trends that demonstrate the platform's ability to produce content that resonates with diverse, international audiences.

Our analysis focuses on three key areas: global content performance, regional market penetration (particularly in high-growth markets like India), and cross-cultural content success stories that exemplify Netflix's "gourmet cheeseburger" philosophy.

## Data Acquisition and Preparation

### Task 1: Data Acquisition

```{r}
#| label: data-acquisition
#| code-summary: "Data Download and Setup"

# Create data directory structure
if(!dir.exists(file.path("data", "mp01"))){
    dir.create(file.path("data", "mp01"), showWarnings=FALSE, recursive=TRUE)
}

# Define file paths
GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME <- file.path("data", "mp01", "global_top10_alltime.csv")
COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME <- file.path("data", "mp01", "country_top10_alltime.csv")

# Download global top 10 data
if(!file.exists(GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME)){
    download.file("https://www.netflix.com/tudum/top10/data/all-weeks-global.tsv", 
                  destfile=GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME)
}

# Download country-specific top 10 data
if(!file.exists(COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME)){
    download.file("https://www.netflix.com/tudum/top10/data/all-weeks-countries.tsv", 
                  destfile=COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME)
}

cat("Data files successfully acquired!\n")
cat("Global Top 10 file size:", file.size(GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME), "bytes\n")
cat("Country Top 10 file size:", file.size(COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME), "bytes\n")
```

### Data Presentation Functions

```{r}
#| label: formatting-functions
#| code-summary: "Create Data Presentation Functions"

# Function to format column names for presentation
format_titles <- function(df){
    colnames(df) <- str_replace_all(colnames(df), "_", " ") |> str_to_title()
    df
}

# Function to create publication-quality tables
create_pub_table <- function(df, caption = NULL, page_length = 10) {
    formatted_df <- df |>
        format_titles()
    
    dt_table <- formatted_df |>
        datatable(
            caption = caption,
            options = list(
                pageLength = page_length,
                searching = TRUE,
                info = TRUE,
                scrollX = TRUE
            ),
            class = 'cell-border stripe'
        )
    
    # Format numeric columns if they exist
    numeric_cols <- names(formatted_df)[sapply(formatted_df, is.numeric)]
    large_number_cols <- numeric_cols[grepl("Hours Viewed|Views|Weekly", numeric_cols)]
    
    if(length(large_number_cols) > 0) {
        dt_table <- dt_table |> 
            formatRound(large_number_cols, digits = 0)
    }
    
    return(dt_table)
}
```

## Task 4: Exploratory Data Analysis

### Question 1: Netflix's Global Reach

```{r}
#| label: countries-count
#| code-summary: "Count Unique Countries"

countries_count <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
    summarise(unique_countries = n_distinct(country_name)) |>
    pull(unique_countries)

cat("Netflix operates in", countries_count, "different countries based on viewing history data.\n")
```

Netflix operates in **`r countries_count`** different countries, demonstrating its truly global reach and the platform's success in penetrating diverse international markets.

### Question 2: Top Non-English Film by Weeks in Top 10

```{r}
#| label: non-english-film
#| code-summary: "Find Top Non-English Film"

top_non_english <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
    filter(category == "Films (Non-English)") |>
    group_by(show_title) |>
    summarise(
        total_weeks = sum(cumulative_weeks_in_top_10),
        max_weeks = max(cumulative_weeks_in_top_10),
        .groups = 'drop'
    ) |>
    arrange(desc(max_weeks)) |>
    slice(1)

cat("Top non-English film:", top_non_english$show_title, "\n")
cat("Weeks in top 10:", top_non_english$max_weeks, "\n")
```

The non-English-language film that has spent the most cumulative weeks in the global top 10 is **`r top_non_english$show_title`**, which spent **`r top_non_english$max_weeks`** weeks in the top 10.

### Question 3: Longest Film in Global Top 10

```{r}
#| label: longest-film
#| code-summary: "Find Longest Film"

longest_film <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
    filter(str_detect(category, "Films")) |>
    filter(!is.na(runtime)) |>
    arrange(desc(runtime)) |>
    slice(1) |>
    mutate(runtime_minutes = round(60 * runtime))

cat("Longest film:", longest_film$show_title, "\n")
cat("Runtime:", longest_film$runtime_minutes, "minutes\n")
cat("Category:", longest_film$category, "\n")
```

The longest film to ever appear in the Netflix global Top 10 is **`r longest_film$show_title`** at **`r longest_film$runtime_minutes`** minutes (`r longest_film$category`).

### Question 4: Top Programs by Category

```{r}
#| label: top-by-category
#| code-summary: "Find Top Program in Each Category"

top_by_category <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
    group_by(category, show_title) |>
    summarise(
        total_hours = sum(weekly_hours_viewed, na.rm = TRUE),
        .groups = 'drop'

```

### Question 9: US Films That Climbed to #1

```{r}
#| label: climbing-films
#| code-summary: "Find Films That Climbed to #1 in US"

# Find films that hit #1 in US
us_number_ones <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
    filter(country_name == "United States" & str_detect(category, "Films") & weekly_rank == 1) |>
    distinct(show_title)

# Find films that didn't debut at #1 but later reached #1
climbing_films <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
    filter(country_name == "United States" & str_detect(category, "Films")) |>
    filter(show_title %in% us_number_ones$show_title) |>
    group_by(show_title) |>
    arrange(week) |>
    summarise(
        first_rank = first(weekly_rank),
        hit_number_1 = any(weekly_rank == 1),
        latest_week = max(week),
        .groups = 'drop'
    ) |>
    filter(first_rank > 1 & hit_number_1) |>
    arrange(desc(latest_week))

climbing_count <- nrow(climbing_films)
most_recent <- climbing_films$show_title[1]
most_recent_date <- climbing_films$latest_week[1]

cat("Number of films that climbed to #1 in US:", climbing_count, "\n")
cat("Most recent film:", most_recent, "\n")
cat("Date:", most_recent_date, "\n")

# Show top climbing films
climbing_films |>
    head(10) |>
    mutate(
        `Show Title` = show_title,
        `First Rank` = first_rank,
        `Hit #1` = hit_number_1,
        `Latest Week` = latest_week
    ) |>
    select(`Show Title`, `First Rank`, `Latest Week`) |>
    create_pub_table(caption = "Films That Climbed to #1 in US (Most Recent First)")
```

**`r climbing_count`** films reached Number 1 in the US after debuting at a lower position. The most recent film to accomplish this feat is **`r most_recent`** in **`r most_recent_date`**.

### Question 10: TV Show with Most International Debut

```{r}
#| label: most-international-debut
#| code-summary: "Find TV Show with Most International Debut"

# Find TV shows/seasons and their debut week performance
international_debuts <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
    filter(str_detect(category, "TV")) |>
    group_by(show_title, season_title) |>
    arrange(week) |>
    slice(1) |>  # Get first appearance (debut week)
    ungroup() |>
    group_by(show_title, season_title, week) |>
    summarise(
        countries_charted = n_distinct(country_name),
        .groups = 'drop'
    ) |>
    arrange(desc(countries_charted)) |>
    slice(1)

top_debut_show <- international_debuts$show_title[1]
top_debut_season <- international_debuts$season_title[1]
top_debut_countries <- international_debuts$countries_charted[1]
top_debut_week <- international_debuts$week[1]

cat("TV show with most international debut:", top_debut_show, "\n")
cat("Season:", ifelse(is.na(top_debut_season), "Not specified", top_debut_season), "\n")
cat("Countries charted:", top_debut_countries, "\n")
cat("Debut week:", top_debut_week, "\n")
```

The TV show/season that hit the top 10 in the most countries in its debut week is **`r top_debut_show`** `r ifelse(is.na(top_debut_season), "", paste("(", top_debut_season, ")"))`**, which charted in **`r top_debut_countries`** countries during its debut week of **`r top_debut_week`**.

### Task 6: Netflix in India Press Release

```{r}
#| label: india-analysis
#| code-summary: "Analyze Netflix Performance in India"

# Analyze Hindi content and India-specific performance
hindi_content <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
    filter(str_detect(category, "Non-English")) |>
    # We'll use a proxy - content that appears in India but not US
    left_join(
        COUNTRY_TOP_10 |> 
        filter(country_name == "India") |> 
        distinct(show_title) |> 
        mutate(in_india = TRUE),
        by = "show_title"
    ) |>
    left_join(
        COUNTRY_TOP_10 |> 
        filter(country_name == "United States") |> 
        distinct(show_title) |> 
        mutate(in_us = TRUE),
        by = "show_title"
    ) |>
    filter(in_india == TRUE & is.na(in_us)) |>
    group_by(show_title, category) |>
    summarise(
        total_hours = sum(weekly_hours_viewed, na.rm = TRUE),
        .groups = 'drop'
    ) |>
    arrange(desc(total_hours))

# India-specific viewing data
india_stats <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
    filter(country_name == "India") |>
    group_by(year(week)) |>
    summarise(
        total_programs = n_distinct(show_title),
        .groups = 'drop'
    ) |>
    arrange(`year(week)`)

# Top India-exclusive content
top_india_content <- hindi_content |>
    head(3)
```
